org.codefarm.engine

Class CodeFormatter

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.codefarm.engine.CodeFormatter

  • public class CodeFormatter
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains a definition of a code including it's length and character set and provides methods to handle excluded characters and to produce the string representations of a BigIneger generated within the code space.

    The class is instantiated with a code length only. If the caller wishes to specify excluded characters, then they must call the initExcludes() method and pass in a char array of excluded characters.

    Instances of CodeGenerator are passed an instance of this class in the constructor. The CodeGenerator uses the instance to calculate the maximum permutations possible in the code space It then uses the instance to produce the code strings from the random BigIntegers generated.

    Author:
    Oliver Thomas

    • Constructor Detail

      • CodeFormatter

        public CodeFormatter(int codeLen)
              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Constructs a new CodeFormatter object for codes of the specified length

        After the constructor call, all alpha-numeric characters are assumed to be usable. If the caller wishes to specify excluded characters then they must call initExclusions, which will re-initialise the exclusions and replacements arrays (initialised to zero size arrays by this constructor)

        Parameters:
        codeLen - the length of the code that this format represents
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the code length does not comply to the limits (limits specified as constants in this class)

      • initExclusions

        public void initExclusions(char[] tempExcludes)
                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Initialises the _excludedChars and _replacementChars internal arrays. Call this after construction in order to exclude characters from the code strings.

        The main idea behind this method is in the way the code string is formed. The code string is formed using the toString method of the BigInteger class. This takes a radix argument and will return the string representation of the BigInteger using that radix (base). Where the radix specified is > 10, the letters will be used for the places above 9. Only the letters A to Z are available, making the maximum radix = 36.

        For example, in base 36, you would count from 1 to 36 like this: 123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ And BigInteger.valueOf(36).toString(36) returns "Z"

        Just like in the decimal counting system, where there are 10 different symbols used to represent numbers, The number of different characters that can be used to create a code will be the radix that is used when calling the toString method.

        Now if some characters are specified as excluded, then the length of the character set, and hence the radix, is reduced. If, for example, the following are excluded: {0, 1, I, L, Y}, then the character set length, and hence the radix, is now 36 - 5 = 31. The toString function will now use all the numbers and all the letters except for the last 5, i.e. {V, W, X, Y, Z}.

        Now we know the characters that must be excluded and the characters that will be excluded anyway due to the reduced radix, we can create an array of the remaining excluded characters that will still appear in the toString return value, and must be replaced with allowed characters. And we can also create an array of the replacement characters by borrowing from the characters that will not appear in the toString return value (at the end of the alphabet).

        These two arrays can then be used by the other methods in order to return the code string representation needed without including any excluded characters, whilst maintaining the uniqueness of the code string.

        The steps to implement are as follows:

        1. Create an array of the [tempExcludes.length] last characters in the ALL_CHARS array (e.g {X, Y, Z} where tempExcludes.length = 3). This is the temporary replacements array

        2. Build new replacement and new exclude arrays by iterating over both temporary arrays in turn:

        - Iterate over each character in excludes and check if it is in replacements.

        If it is not found in replacements, then it will not be excluded automatically by the effect of the reduced radix string and must be excluded explicitly.

        - Iterate over each character in replacements and check if it is in excludes.

        If it is not found then it is not excluded and may be used to provide a replacement character.

        3. Initialise the instance variables by resizing (reducing) the arrays built in step 2.

        Parameters:
        tempExcludes - a char array of all excluded characters, as passed into the constructor of this instance

        NOTE: this argument is called tempExcludes because the final value of _excludedChars will not include any characters that are excluded anyway due to reduced radix.

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If any of the passed in exclusion characters are not alpha-numeric, or if the resulting character set is less than the minimum (limits specified as constants in this class)
